title: Tplyr table module
text: mod_Tplyr_table features following outputs: table created using Tplyr package corresponding listing selected cell table. standalone listing dv.tables::mod_Tplyr_table() module uses several arguments following mandatory rest optional. part app creation, app creator specify values arguments applicable. Mandatory Arguments module_id : unique identifier type character module output_list: named list defining outputs generated. element list corresponds table listing must named list one following structures: summary tables: tplyr_tab_fun function takes one datasets input returns tplyr_table object. build_fun function takes tplyr_table object returns built table (typically using Tplyr::build()).Note: metadata argument Tplyr::build() needs set TURE, corresponding listing can shown. standalone listings: dataset_names character vector dataset names required generate listing. names top-level list elements used identifiers outputs. subjid_var Column corresponding subject ID. Default value ‘USUBJID’ (Optional) Arguments listing customization module uses {dv.listings} showing drill-listing data. Therefore additional arguments can provided customization. default_vars, pagination, intended_use_label, receiver_id, review arguments passed {dv.listings}. information can found

title: Tplyr table module
text: better understand set module can follow example: First load dummy data: Create Tplyr table wrap function. Create build function tplyr table created first step Create output_list passed dv.tables::mod_Tplyr_table Put everything together start app within {dv.manager} ’s also possible add one table module. last step can also add standalone listing module
code: # load demo data dm <- pharmaversesdtm::dm my_tplyr_fun <- function(dm) {   tab <- Tplyr::tplyr_table(dm, ARM) |>     Tplyr::add_layer(Tplyr::group_desc(AGE, by = "Age (years)")) |>     Tplyr::add_layer(Tplyr::group_count(SEX, by = "Sex")) |>     Tplyr::add_layer(Tplyr::group_count(RACE, by = "Race"))   return(tab) } build_func <- function(tab) {   Tplyr::build(tab, metadata = TRUE) |>     dplyr::mutate(       row_label2 = ifelse(row_label2 == row_label1, "Total (%)", row_label2)       ) |>     Tplyr::apply_row_masks(row_breaks = TRUE) } output_list <- list(   "Demographic" = list(     tplyr_tab_fun = my_tplyr_fun,     build_fun = build_func   ) ) module_list <- list(   "Table" = dv.tables::mod_Tplyr_table(     module_id = "tplyr_table",     output_list = output_list   ) )  dv.manager::run_app(   data = list("My data" = list(dm = dm)),   module_list = module_list,   filter_data = "dm",   enable_dataset_filter = TRUE ) # load additional demo data dm <- pharmaversesdtm::dm   # create second tplyr table my_tplyr_fun2 <- function(dm, ae) {   dm_arm <- dm |> dplyr::select(USUBJID, ARM)   ae_arm <- ae |> dplyr::inner_join(dm_arm, by = "USUBJID")      tab <- Tplyr::tplyr_table(ae_arm, ARM) |>     Tplyr::set_pop_data(dm) |>     Tplyr::set_pop_treat_var(ARM) |>     Tplyr::add_layer(       Tplyr::group_count("All subjects") |>         Tplyr::set_distinct_by(USUBJID) |>         Tplyr::set_format_strings(Tplyr::f_str("xx", distinct_total))     ) |>     Tplyr::add_layer(       Tplyr::group_count("Subjects with adverse events") |>         Tplyr::set_distinct_by(USUBJID) |>         Tplyr::set_format_strings(Tplyr::f_str("xx (xx %)", distinct_n, distinct_pct))     ) |>     Tplyr::add_layer(       Tplyr::group_count(AESEV, by = "Adverse event severity") |>         Tplyr::set_distinct_by(USUBJID) |>         Tplyr::set_format_strings(Tplyr::f_str("xx (xx %)", distinct_n, distinct_pct))     ) |>     Tplyr::add_layer(       Tplyr::group_count("Subjects with serious AE", where = AESER == "Y") |>         Tplyr::set_distinct_by(USUBJID) |>         Tplyr::set_format_strings(Tplyr::f_str("xx (xx %)", distinct_n, distinct_pct))     )   return(tab) }  # create secod build function  build_func2 <- function(tab) {   Tplyr::build(tab, metadata = TRUE) |>     Tplyr::apply_row_masks(row_breaks = TRUE) }  # put second table into the output_list output_list <- list(   "Demographic" = list(     tplyr_tab_fun = my_tplyr_fun,     build_fun = build_func   ),   "Adverse Events" = list(     tplyr_tab_fun = my_tplyr_fun2,     build_fun = build_func   ) )  # put everything together  module_list <- list(   "Table" = dv.tables::mod_Tplyr_table(     module_id = "tplyr_table",     output_list = output_list   ) ) # start app dv.manager::run_app(   data = list("My data" = list(ae = ae, dm = dm)),   module_list = module_list,   filter_data = "dm",   enable_dataset_filter = TRUE ) # Add additional entry for standalone listings output_list <- list(   "Demographic" = list(     tplyr_tab_fun = my_tplyr_fun,     build_fun = build_func   ),   "Adverse Events" = list(     tplyr_tab_fun = my_tplyr_fun2,     build_fun = build_func   ),   "Listing" = list(     dataset_names = c("dm", "ae")   ) ) # put everything together  module_list <- list(   "Table" = dv.tables::mod_Tplyr_table(     module_id = "tplyr_table",     output_list = output_list   ) ) # start app dv.manager::run_app(   data = list("My data" = list(ae = ae, dm = dm)),   module_list = module_list,   filter_data = "dm",   enable_dataset_filter = TRUE )

title: Event Count module
text: hierarchical_count_table features following tables: hierarchy table arranged highest lowest event count normalized population. supports bookmarking.

title: Event Count module
text: dv.tables::mod_hierarchical_count_table() module uses several arguments following mandatory rest optional. part app creation, app creator specify values arguments applicable. Mandatory Arguments module_id : unique identifier type character module app. subjid_var: common column across datasets uniquely identify subjects. default: “SUBJID” table_dataset_name: dataset contains events per row. example, ADAE pop_dataset_name: dataset contains one row per subject total population. example, ADSL expects dataset structure similar https://www.cdisc.org/kb/examples/adam-subject-level-analysis-adsl-dataset-80283806 , one record per subject expects contain, least, subjid_var Refer dv.tables::mod_hierarchical_count_table() complete list arguments description.

title: Event Count module
text: module allows downloading table Excel (.xlsx) Word (.rtf). downloaded table, overall number patients (N = seen selected group’s column header) shown first row column names. Additionally, option split count percent separate columns selected, selected group variable’s metrics split two columns every group item, {group item} [N] show count value {group item} [%] show relative percentage.

title: Server for the Tplyr_table module — Tplyr_table_server
text: module_id [character(1)] character string serves unique identifier module. dataset_list [shiny::reactive(list(data.frame)] reactive list data.framish dataset(s) used create table listing(s). output_list [list(list())] named list defining outputs generated. element list corresponds table listing must named list one following structures: summary tables: tplyr_tab_fun function takes one datasets input returns tplyr_table object. build_fun function takes tplyr_table object returns built table (typically using Tplyr::build()). metadata argument Tplyr::build() needs set TURE, corresponding listing can shown. listings: dataset_names character vector dataset names required generate listing. names top-level list elements used identifiers outputs. dataset_metadata [list(character(1), character(1+))] list following two elements: dataset_metadata$name() containing reactive string specifying name selected dataset dataset_metadata$date_range() containing reactive character vector two entries specifying earliest latest modification date dataset. Usually obtained module manager. subjid_var [character(1) | NULL] Column corresponding subject ID. Default value 'USUBJID' default_vars argument listings_server dv.listings passed . intended_use_label argument listings_server dv.listings passed . pagination argument listings_server dv.listings passed . on_sbj_click argument listings_server dv.listings passed . review argument listings_server dv.listings passed .

title: Computes an event table with subject counts and percentages — compute_events_table
text: event_df data.frame data frame containing event data. columns corresponding subjects, hierarchy levels, group variables. pop_df data.frame data frame containing population data. must columns corresponding subjects group variables. hierarchy character(1|2) character vector column names event_df use hierarchy. Can one two levels. group_var character(1) string representing column name pop_df used grouping population data. subjid_var character(1) string representing subject identifier column name. column must present event_df pop_df. .special_char character(1) special character used internally naming processing hierarchy levels. Default "\u001D". columns must factors

text: module_id [character(1)] character string serves unique identifier module. output_list [list(list())] named list defining outputs generated. element list corresponds table listing must named list one following structures: summary tables: tplyr_tab_fun function takes one datasets input returns tplyr_table object. build_fun function takes tplyr_table object returns built table (typically using Tplyr::build()). metadata argument Tplyr::build() needs set TURE, corresponding listing can shown. listings: dataset_names character vector dataset names required generate listing. names top-level list elements used identifiers outputs. subjid_var [character(1) | NULL] Column corresponding subject ID. Default value 'USUBJID' default_vars argument listings_server dv.listings passed . pagination argument listings_server dv.listings passed . intended_use_label argument listings_server dv.listings passed . receiver_id argument listings_server dv.listings passed review argument listings_server dv.listings passed .

title: Tplyr table module for DaVinci's module manager — mod_Tplyr_table
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ dm <- pharmaversesdtm::dm ae <- pharmaversesdtm::ae  my_tplyr_fun <- function(dm) {   tab <- Tplyr::tplyr_table(dm, ARM) |>     Tplyr::add_layer(Tplyr::group_desc(AGE, by = "Age (years)")) |>     Tplyr::add_layer(Tplyr::group_count(SEX, by = "Sex")) |>     Tplyr::add_layer(Tplyr::group_count(RACE, by = "Race"))   return(tab) }  build_func <- function(tab) {   Tplyr::build(tab, metadata = TRUE) |>     dplyr::mutate(row_label2 = ifelse(row_label2 == row_label1, "Total (%)", row_label2)) |>     Tplyr::apply_row_masks(row_breaks = TRUE) }  my_tplyr_fun2 <- function(dm, ae) {   dm_arm <- dm |> dplyr::select(USUBJID, ARM)   ae_arm <- ae |> dplyr::inner_join(dm_arm, by = "USUBJID")    tab <- Tplyr::tplyr_table(ae_arm, ARM) |>     Tplyr::set_pop_data(dm) |>     Tplyr::set_pop_treat_var(ARM) |>     Tplyr::add_layer(       Tplyr::group_count("All subjects") |>       Tplyr::set_distinct_by(USUBJID) |>       Tplyr::set_format_strings(Tplyr::f_str("xx", distinct_total))     ) |>     Tplyr::add_layer(       Tplyr::group_count("Subjects with adverse events") |>         Tplyr::set_distinct_by(USUBJID) |>         Tplyr::set_format_strings(Tplyr::f_str("xx (xx %)", distinct_n, distinct_pct))     ) |>     Tplyr::add_layer(       Tplyr::group_count(AESEV, by = "Adverse event severity") |>       Tplyr::set_distinct_by(USUBJID) |>       Tplyr::set_format_strings(Tplyr::f_str("xx (xx %)", distinct_n, distinct_pct))     ) |>     Tplyr::add_layer(       Tplyr::group_count("Subjects with serious AE", where = AESER == "Y") |>         Tplyr::set_distinct_by(USUBJID) |>         Tplyr::set_format_strings(Tplyr::f_str("xx (xx %)", distinct_n, distinct_pct))     )   return(tab) }  build_func2 <- function(tab) {   Tplyr::build(tab, metadata = TRUE) |>     Tplyr::apply_row_masks(row_breaks = TRUE) }  output_list <- list(   "Demographic" = list(     tplyr_tab_fun = my_tplyr_fun,     build_fun = build_func   ),   "Adverse Events" = list(     tplyr_tab_fun = my_tplyr_fun2,     build_fun = build_func   ),   "Listing" = list(     dataset_names = c("dm", "ae")   ) )  module_list <- list(   "Table" = dv.tables::mod_Tplyr_table(     module_id = "tplyr_table",     output_list = output_list   ) )  dv.manager::run_app(   data = list("My data" = list(ae = ae, dm = dm)),   module_list = module_list,   filter_data = "dm",   enable_dataset_filter = TRUE )  } # }

code: hierarchical_count_table_ui(id)  hierarchical_count_table_server(   id,   table_dataset,   pop_dataset,   subjid_var,   show_modal_on_click = TRUE,   on_sbj_click_fun = function() NULL,   default_hierarchy = NULL,   default_group = NULL,   hierarchy_choices = NULL,   group_choices = NULL,   intended_use_label = NULL )  mod_hierarchical_count_table(   module_id,   table_dataset_name,   pop_dataset_name,   subjid_var = "USUBJID",   show_modal_on_click = TRUE,   default_hierarchy = NULL,   default_group = NULL,   hierarchy_choices = NULL,   group_choices = NULL,   intended_use_label =     "Use only for internal review and monitoring during the conduct of clinical trials.",   receiver_id = NULL )

title: Invoke hierarchical_count_table module — hierarchical_count_table_ui
text: id character(0) ID event count module instance. table_dataset data.frame reactive dataset containing event data. pop_dataset data.frame reactive dataset containing population data. subjid_var character(1) string representing subject identifier column datasets. show_modal_on_click logical(1) flag indicate whether clicking table cell display modal dialog subject IDs. on_sbj_click_fun 'function()' Function invoke subject clicked default_hierarchy character(1|2)|NULL default value hierarchy variables (optional). default_group character(1)|NULL default value group variable (optional). hierarchy_choices character(1+)|NULL character vector specifying possible choices hierarchy variables (optional). group_choices character(1+)|NULL character vector specifying possible choices group variable (optional). intended_use_label Either string indicating intended use export, NULL. provided label displayed prior download also included exported file. module_id [character(1)] Module Shiny id table_dataset_name, pop_dataset_name [character(1)] Name dataset receiver_id character(1) Shiny ID module receiving selected subject ID data listing. ID must present app NULL. table_dataset_disp, pop_dataset_disp [mm_dispatcher(1)] Dataset dispatcher. parameter incompatible *_dataset_name counterpart. advanced use.

what: Build a collection of named constants — pack_of_constants

title: Build a collection of named constants — pack_of_constants
Build a collection of named constants — pack_of_constants
text: ... Named parameters collected constants

title: Build a collection of named constants — pack_of_constants
text: Shiny uses strings IDs link UI server elements. E.g: foo_UI(id = ns("foo")) ... foo_server(id = "foo") pattern makes easy programmers fall trap modifying one instance string literal "foo" without modifying rest unaware problem bug hit. also easy mistakes uses "foo" identifier uses (text labels, ...) , often case, parameter explicitly named. One easy fix consists using global variables instead plain string literals. case previous example, mean: ID_FOO <- "foo" foo_UI(ns(ID_FOO)) ... foo_server(ID_FOO) simple addition makes purpose ID_FOO clear also fails gracefully ID_FOO instances updated synchronously along codebase. drawback polluting global namespace identifier variables. easily solved creating container constants, purpose pack_of_constants alias. ID <- pack_of_constants(FOO = "foo", BAR = "bar") ID$FOO "foo" ID$BA Error $.pack_of_constants(ID, BA) : Pack constants "ID" contain "BA" pack constants plain named list enforces elements unique, non-null names. tagged S3 object override extraction operators. use checkmate unnecessary, Good Library(TM) module rely anyways
